aliases.name: Demonic Possession
aliases.meaning: Possession by demons or evil spirits

description.summary: Belief that spirits or demons can inhabit and control human bodies, manifesting as personality changes, speaking unknown languages (glossolalia), superhuman strength, and aversion to sacred objects.
description.full: Possession is the belief that spirits, demons, or other entities can inhabit and control human bodies. Characteristics include dramatic personality changes, speaking unknown languages (glossolalia or xenoglossy), superhuman strength, knowledge of hidden things, convulsions, and aversion to sacred objects. Types vary by culture: demonic possession (Christian), spirit possession (various cultures), and voluntary possession (shamanic traditions). Famous cases include Anneliese Michel (1976, Germany) and Roland Doe (1949, inspiration for 'The Exorcist'). Theories range from genuine spiritual possession (religious view) to mental illness explanations including dissociative identity disorder (DID), schizophrenia, epilepsy, and cultural syndrome. Scientific consensus attributes symptoms to psychiatric conditions, though possession remains an active religious belief worldwide requiring cultural sensitivity.

origins.folklore_connections: Connected to broader beliefs about spirits, souls, and supernatural influence

German woman died during exorcism; criminal trial followed

history.modern_era: Possession beliefs remain strong in many cultures. Catholic Church continues to train exorcists; Protestant deliverance ministries active; Islamic ruqya widely practiced. Medical community treats as psychiatric conditions. Cultural sensitivity increasingly recognized in mental health care.

notable.name: Anneliese Michel
notable.description: German woman underwent 67 exorcism sessions over 10 months. Died of malnutrition and dehydration. Priests and parents charged with negligent homicide. Medical records showed epilepsy and psychiatric conditions.

credibility.notes: Demonstrates dangers of treating psychiatric conditions as possession

sources: Goodman, F. (2005). The Exorcism of Anneliese Michel

notable.name: Roland Doe (pseudonym)
notable.description: 14-year-old boy allegedly possessed; underwent Catholic exorcism ritual. Case inspired William Peter Blatty's novel 'The Exorcist.' Later investigations suggest psychiatric issues and possible hoax elements.
notable.outcome: Claimed successful exorcism; individual lived normal life

credibility.notes: Cultural impact significant despite questionable details

sources: Original diary entries from attending priest

physical.description: No physical evidence of actual spirit/demon possession; all evidence is behavioral and subjective

medical.description: Medical evaluations consistently find psychiatric conditions in alleged possession cases

scientific.name: Schizophrenia and Psychotic Disorders

scientific.description: Seizures causing altered consciousness, personality changes, religious experiences

scientific.name: Cultural Syndrome
scientific.description: Culture-bound syndrome; symptoms shaped by cultural expectations and beliefs
evidence_cited: Higher prevalence in cultures with possession beliefs

scientific.name: Suggestion and Social Contagion
scientific.description: Symptoms arise from suggestion, expectation, and social influence
